AssessmentQuestions.Question: 1. Do you manage code branch for each Project Work Request (PWR)?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Every Project
  Work Request has a version control branch associated with it so that there is
  alignment between the technology that is undergoing a change request

AssessmentQuestions.Question: 2. Are code branches and code commits tagged & baselined so that all change requests are traceable?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
All
  change requests are easily traceable via a simple dashboard which gives the
  user a very transparent insight in to the release pipeline which enables to
  point out build fails or errors easily and to have more control over the
  applications and the deployments

AssessmentQuestions.Question: 3. Are the code artifacts published to a central repository?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
All the artifacts
  are uploaded in a central repository which is easily accessible and also for
  other contributors to easily update and sync the changes in seconds time

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
4. Is the
  code requiring external compile/ run time dependencies pulled from a single
  repository?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
All
  the code streams which requires external compile or runtime dependencies are
  able to retrieve from a central repository

SubQuestion.Question:
4.1.1 
  How do you rate
  your code repository management process?

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
5. Do you follow Test
  or Behaviour Driven Development (TDD/ BDD) approach for high levels of code
  coverage in testing?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Development teams
  follow Test-Driven Development and Behaviour-Driven Development demonstrating
  which covers high levels of code coverage from unit testing to assembly
  testing.

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
6. Are code releases
  subject to a staged roll out and piloting phase?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Releases done by
  your team are deployed in stages including a pilot phase where it is not in
  production.

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
7. 
  Do you follow Test
  or Behaviour Driven Development (TDD/ BDD) approach for high levels of code
  coverage in testing?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Development teams
  follow Test-Driven Development and Behaviour-Driven Development demonstrating
  which covers high levels of code coverage from unit testing to assembly
  testing.

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
8. 
  Is the development
  environment (IDE, source code and server config) setup automated?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Environment
  provisioning  is an ideal state as it
  allows users to focus on applying identical environment configurations by a
  single click

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
12. 
  Are your
  deployments traceable end to end?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
All
  the actions are clearly traceable after deployment of the project using the
  simple dashboard

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
13. 
  Are
  deployments non-impacting and can take place during business hours?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Releases
  done by your team are deployed in stages including a pilot phase where it is
  not in production.

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
14. 
  Are
  applications deployed Active-Active across DR and Production?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Applications
  are deployed under Single Machine High Availability across Disaster Recovery
  and Production servers

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
15. 
  Are
  alerting controls in place for all assets in the application and its boundary
  points?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
Alerting
  is enabled for asset availability within the application as well as for all
  application boundaries

AssessmentQuestions.Question:
16. 
  Do you
  follow a defined workflow for change management across environments?
AssessmentQuestions.Description:
All
  the change requests are tracked and managed using a JIRA workflow which is
  used specifically to handle them

  Are environment changes easily managed using the environment provisioning
